conversation.text: Hello! We are going to cook plantains! To start grab some vegetable oil and a deep skillet.
evidence: Heat 1 ⁄2 cups (350 ml) of vegetable oil in a skillet to 375 °F (191 °C)

conversation.text: Okay I have the skillet and the vegetable oil ready.
Perfect. Place the skillet on the stove and pour 1/2 cup of vegetable oil in the pan.
evidence: Heat 1 ⁄2 cups (350 ml) of vegetable oil in a skillet to 375 °F (191 °C).

conversation.text: Okay I have poured the 1/2 cup in the vegetable oil into the pan.
Next turn on the burner to medium to high heat. You want to heat the oil to 375 deg C. Hold a deep fry thermometer to the side of the skillet in the oil to track the temperature.
evidence: Clip a deep-fry thermometer to the side of the skillet and turn the burner to medium-high heat. Heat the oil until it reaches 375 °F

conversation.text: What should I do if I do not have a deep fry thermometer? I can't seem to find mine.
You can just heat it until it shimmers!
evidence: If you don't have a deep-fry thermometer, heat the oil until it shimmers.

conversation.text: Oh I found mine so I can use the deep fry thermometer.
Perfect. What is the temperature your oil is at now? If it goes above 375 degrees please turn down the burner a little.
evidence: Heat the oil until it reaches 375 °F (191 °C). If the oil continues to heat past 375 °F (191 °C), turn the burner down a little

conversation.text: The temperature of my oil is exactly 375 degrees
Perfect. Do you have the plantain slices ready?
evidence: When you think it's ready, lower 1 piece of plantain into the oil.

conversation.text: Yes the slices are ready to go

Perfect let's test the oil! Place one piece of plantain into the oil and see if the oil bubbles. If it does we are ready to fry the plantain. If it doesn't we will wait a minute for it to heat up some more.
evidence: lower 1 piece of plantain into the oil. If the oil is hot enough, it will immediately begin to bubble and fry. If it doesn't, wait another minute and check again.

conversation.text: I put the plantain piece into the oil and it started to bubble right away. Is that okay?
Yes that is great! We can now place another 4 slices of the plantain into the oil.
evidence: If the oil is hot enough, it will immediately begin to bubble and fry.
Place 4 or 5 pieces of plantains into the hot oil.

conversation.text: It there any specific way I should be placing them in the oil or can I just drop them in?

It is best to not drop the plantains in as the oil could splash you. Use your hands to slowly lower the plantain pieces into the oil. If you are still getting splashed by the hot oil you can also use a slotted spoon to place the plantain slices.
evidence: Use your hands to slowly lower 4 or 5 of these pieces into the oil, taking care not to drop them or the oil could splash you.
If you're concerned that the oil will burn you, place the plantain pieces on a slotted spoon and lower it directly into the oil.

conversation.text: Okay I will use a slotted spoon thank you! How long should the cook in the oil for?

Cook the slices for 4 to 5 minutes and flip halfway through. It is best to set a timer so you do not lose track of time! So you can set a time for 2 minutes and flip the pieces and then set the timer for another 2 minutes.
evidence: Fry the plantains for 4 to 5 minutes

conversation.text: Okay the two minutes is now up. I will flip the plantain slices.
What colour are the plantain slices on the side now facing up, the side that has cooked?
evidence: et the plantain pieces fry until they're a rich golden brown

conversation.text: The are a little golden brown on that side. And now the other two minutes is up, do I remove the slices?

If the plantain slices are a golden brown on both sides they are done and can be removed from the pan. Transfer the fried slices to a paper towel on a plate, the paper towel will absorb the grease. You can remove the slices with a spatula or spoon.
evidence: let the plantain pieces fry until they're a rich golden brow

conversation.text: Perfect. Do I just repeat those steps with the other slices now?
Yes continue to do batch of 4-5 slices. Be sure between each batch that the oil is heated up to 375 degrees. If the plantains are browning too fast turn down the burner.
evidence: Remember to let the oil heat back up to 375 °F (191 °C) before you fry another batch of plantains.
Lower the burner temperature if the plantains are browning too fast.

conversation.text: Okay I have fried the rest of the batches.
Perfect. How would you like to eat your plantains? You can add some sugar and salt on them or just leaves them plain.
evidence: Season the fried plantains any way you like or leave them plain.
Season the fried plantains any way you like or leave them plain.

conversation.text: I would like to make them a little sweet with some sugar and salt.
Okay sprinkle a little bit of sugar or salt on the plantains and then they are ready to eat! It is best to eat them fresh and hot since they do not store well.
evidence: Sprinkle a little salt or sugar over the plantains.

conversation.text: These are very yummy thank you. Can I store some for leftovers if I cannot eat them all?
You for sure can! I would recommend if you eat them later that you re-fry them for the best taste and texture!
evidence: while plantains that are fried twice are called tostones.

conversation.text: Perfect I will try that. Thank you for your help!
You are welcome, hope you enjoy!
evidence: Enjoy

conversation.text: I am, thanks again!

procedure.summary: Heat 1 ⁄2 cups (350 ml) of vegetable oil in a skillet to 375 °F (191 °C).
procedure.description: Set a deep skillet on the stove and pour in the vegetable oil. Clip a deep-fry thermometer to the side of the skillet and turn the burner to medium-high heat. Heat the oil until it reaches 375 °F (191 °C). If the oil continues to heat past 375 °F (191 °C), turn the burner down a little. If you don't have a deep-fry thermometer, heat the oil until it shimmers. When you think it's ready, lower 1 piece of plantain into the oil. If the oil is hot enough, it will immediately begin to bubble and fry. If it doesn't, wait another minute and check again.

procedure.summary: Place 4 or 5 pieces of plantains into the hot oil.
procedure.description: Set 4 large plantains that you've sliced into 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces on your cutting board. Use your hands to slowly lower 4 or 5 of these pieces into the oil, taking care not to drop them or the oil could splash you. If you're concerned that the oil will burn you, place the plantain pieces on a slotted spoon and lower it directly into the oil. It's important to fry the plantains in batches so the temperature of the oil doesn't drop quickly.

procedure.summary: Fry the plantains for 4 to 5 minutes.
procedure.description: Set a timer and let the plantain pieces fry until they're a rich golden brown. Use a slotted spatula or spoon to carefully flip them over halfway through the frying time. This ensures that they become crispy and brown on both sides. Lower the burner temperature if the plantains are browning too fast.

procedure.summary: Transfer the fried plantains to a paper towel-lined plate.
procedure.description: Take the slotted spatula or spoon and carefully move the fried plantains to a lined plate. The paper towel will absorb excess grease. Remember to let the oil heat back up to 375 °F (191 °C) before you fry another batch of plantains.

procedure.summary: Sprinkle a little salt or sugar over the plantains.
procedure.description: Season the fried plantains any way you like or leave them plain. Enjoy the plantains while they're hot since they won't store well.Did You Know? Fried plantains are sometimes called maduros, while plantains that are fried twice are called tostones.
